item.title: Lens Blog: The World’s Best (Unaltered) Photos
item.description: World Press Photo announced the winners of its 2013 contest while its judges lamented the proliferation of Photoshop, which disqualified several top contenders.
item.dc:creator: By JAMES ESTRIN
item.media:description: A cluster of countries in Central America — Honduras, Guatemala and El Salvador — makes up one of the most violent regions in the world. In many cases, clothes that are found become the only means to identify victims, like this woman's clothing found at a sugar plantation in Apopa, San Salvador. She was 17 or 18 years old. First place, daily life stories.

item.title: Obama Promises New Aid to Jordan in Refugee Crisis
item.description: The president announced the economic package during a meeting in Rancho Mirage, Calif., with King Abdullah II of Jordan.
item.dc:creator: By SARAH WHEATON and MARK LANDLER

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: South China Sea Tensions a Backdrop to Kerry’s China Visit
item.description: Chinese officials take exception to statements by a U.S. Navy admiral that Washington would fulfill its obligations under a mutual defense treaty to help the Philippines if it came under attack
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.dc:creator: By KEITH BRADSHER

item.title: 2 Companies to Destroy Chemicals in Syria’s Arsenal
item.description: The Organization for the Prohibition of Chemical Weapons chose hazardous-waste disposal companies based in the United States and Finland.
item.category: Organization for the Prohibition of Chemical Weapons
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: Medicines Made in India Set Off Safety Worries
item.description: India, the second largest exporter of over-the-counter and prescription drugs to the United States, is coming under increased scrutiny by American regulators.
item.dc:creator: By GARDINER HARRIS
item.media:description: Dr. Margaret A. Hamburg, the head of the Food and Drug Administration, is in India this week to express her concerns.

item.title: Trade Pact With Asia Faces Imposing Hurdle: Midterm Politics
item.description: Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. acknowledged that Congress will not grant President Obama fast-track trade promotion authority, which analysts call critical for deals with Asia and Europe.
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.dc:creator: By MARK LANDLER and JONATHAN WEISMAN
item.media:description: Representative Nancy Pelosi on Friday at the Democratic Issues Conference in Cambridge, Md.

item.title: The Saturday Profile: Political Star Rises on Vow to Upend Italy’s Old Order
item.description: Matteo Renzi engineered the Italian prime minister’s removal and is poised to succeed him, but now he faces the challenge of shaking the country out of its malaise.
item.dc:creator: By JIM YARDLEY
item.media:description: “This road is more difficult, rather than waiting for a slow attrition, because putting myself on the line now has an element of personal risk,” says Matteo Renzi, who is poised to become Italy's youngest prime minister.

item.title: U.S. and Canada Feel Putin Charm, Hockey Excluded
item.description: The Russian president visited the headquarters of the American and Canadian teams on Friday, part of his personal outreach at the Games.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN

item.title: Pope Pressed on Bishop Who Supervised Pedophile
item.description: Parishioners argued that Bishop Robert W. Finn should be subject to disciplinary action by the church for failing to notify authorities that a priest in his diocese was an active pedophile.
item.dc:creator: By LAURIE GOODSTEIN
item.media:credit: Steve Hebert for The New York Times
item.media:description: Jill McQueen worshiped with other parishioners at St. Patrick Catholic Church in Kansas City, Mo., at a Sunday Mass in 2011.

item.title: Roots of Bosnian Protests Lie in Peace Accords of 1995
item.description: The violence that erupted a week ago across Bosnia and Herzegovina can be traced to the 1995 Dayton Accords, which brought peace but imposed a dysfunctional government that has stymied progress.
item.dc:creator: By ALISON SMALE
item.media:credit: Ziyah Gafic for The New York Times
item.media:description: Protesters this week in Sarajevo, the capital, one of dozens of cities across Bosnia where long-simmering frustrations with the government have erupted.

item.title: Guantánamo Bay Prosecutors Accuse Detainee of Conspiracy
item.description: The move could set up a test of whether Congress may make conspiracy, not recognized as a war crime, something able to be prosecuted in a war-crimes tribunal.
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: By CHARLIE SAVAGE

item.title: Deadlock Remains and Aid Crisis Mounts as 2nd Round of Syria Talks Nears End
item.description: New tensions between the meeting’s sponsors, Russia and the United States, appeared to complicate the negotiations.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
National Coalition of Syrian Revolutionary and Opposition Forces
item.dc:creator: By ANNE BARNARD
item.media:description: A man holds a baby in his arms following a reported airstrike in the northern Syrian city of Aleppo on Friday.

item.title: The Lede: Deferential Remarks in Martyrdom Video Said to Show Briton’s Last Words Before Suicide Attack in Syria
item.description: Video posted online appears to show a British man politely declining to speak in his own martyrdom video, just before a suicide attack in Syria.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY and CHRISTINE HAUSER
item.media:description: A British man, dressed for martyrdom in a screen shot from video said to have been recorded in Syria last week before a suicide attack.

item.title: World Briefing: Thailand: Police Push Back, Briefly
item.description: The police cleared protesters from a major boulevard in Bangkok as part of an effort to reclaim areas that have been closed during a push to unseat Prime Minister Yingluck Shinawatra.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Bahrain: Crackdown on Protesters
item.description: Clashes between security forces and antigovernment protesters on the third anniversary of the nation’s uprising left dozens wounded, the authorities and activists said Friday.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Central African Republic: Muslims Try to Flee but Are Turned Back
item.description: A convoy of thousands of Muslims was turned back because peacekeepers feared that they would be attacked on their way through some parts of the capital, Bangui.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: China Set to Press North Korea Further on Nuclear Aims, Kerry Says
item.description: The secretary of state said he urged Chinese leaders to “use every tool at their disposal” to persuade North Korea to rethink its nuclear ambitions.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL R. GORDON

item.title: The World Celebrates Valentine's Day
item.description: From a hugging marathon in Thailand to naked bungee jumping in Latvia, different cultures celebrate Valentine’s Day in their own way.

item.title: Italy’s Premier Leaves Post Amid Dispute
item.description: President Giorgio Napolitano is widely expected to ask Matteo Renzi, the brash young mayor of Florence, to form a new government after the resignation of Prime Minister Enrico Letta.
item.dc:creator: By ELISABETTA POVOLEDO
item.media:description: Prime Minister Enrico Letta of Italy left his house in Rome on Friday. His resignation came a day after his party voted to replace him with its new leader, Matteo Renzi, the mayor of Florence.

item.title: Chief Minister of Delhi Resigns After 49 Days, Citing Resistance to Antigraft Bill
item.description: In stepping down, Arvind Kejriwal said his central anticorruption initiative was being stonewalled by legislators from two well-established parties.
item.dc:creator: By ELLEN BARRY and MALAVIKA VYAWAHARE
item.media:description: Arvind Kejriwal, Delhi’s chief minister, with his resignation letter in hand, on Friday.

item.title: World Briefing : Venezuela’s Leader Pulls Foreign Channel Over Protest Coverage
item.description: President Nicolás Maduro said that the channel, Colombia-based NTN24, had tried to “foment anxiety about a coup d’état.”
item.dc:creator: By WILLIAM NEUMAN

item.title: In Libya, a Coup. Or Perhaps Not.
item.description: Stealing a page from neighboring Egypt, a senior army officer in Libya announced a military takeover. But no one seemed to be taking him seriously.
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.dc:creator: By DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK

item.title: Indonesian Arms Industry Seeks to Drum Up Business
item.description: President Susilo Bambang Yudhoyono has vowed to modernize the country’s military and has nearly quadrupled the state arms budget.
item.dc:creator: By JOE COCHRANE
item.media:description: President Susilo Bambang Yudhoyono, center, with a South Korean-built T-50i light fighter jet.

item.title: A Minister in Germany Steps Down Amid Uproar
item.description: Hans-Peter Friedrich defended his decision to tip off fellow members of the Social Democrats that the police were looking into a colleague.
item.dc:creator: By ALISON SMALE
item.media:description: Agriculture Minister Hans-Peter Friedrich resigned Friday.

item.title: France and Germany Lead Euro Zone to Higher Growth
item.description: Growth is still weak, at a 1.1 percent annualized rate, but indicates that the bloc is well beyond the year-and-a-half recession that ended last year.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID JOLLY
item.media:description: A container port near Hamburg, Germany. Stronger foreign trade contributed to German economic growth in the fourth quarter of 2013.
